pulls.title: add package detail to about page

package_json.name: @fuz.dev/fuz
package_json.description: design system for CSS, Svelte, and SvelteKit

package_json.name: @grogarden/gro
package_json.description: task runner and toolkit extending SvelteKit

scripts.build: rm -rf .gro dist && svelte-package && chmod +x ./dist/gro.js && npm link -f

pulls.title: add and integrate `gro changelog`
pulls.body: - [ ] map leading hashes to the PR, fallback to the hash link

pulls.title: change .well-known/package.json to use the static directory
pulls.body:
If you link to the .well-known/package.json, SvelteKit won't see it during the build. I think the build is fine, it just fixes the error.

I knew this was the better implementation but I was being lazy, it's more work and I want to make reusable helpers for creating the file temporarily and then cleaning up.

like

```ts
const cleanup = copy_temporarily(...)
```

(similar usecase with `"public": true` and `src/`)

or maybe a Vite plugin, so the path works during development too and without any filesystem stuff? but can Gro do that without being intrusive to configure?

pulls.title: stop using the `deploy` branch in the main cwd for `gro deploy`
pulls.body:
vscode flips out regularly from the workspace-destructive `deploy` branch in `gro deploy`. This refactors the internals to use a non-destructive strategy, at the cost of inefficiency -- a `.git` directory for the `deploy` branch is now duplicated in a cache directory. A benefit is that you no longer see `deploy` in your root `.git` context.

- maybe `.gro/deploy`?
- `git clone -b deploy --single-branch git://github.com/grogarden/gro.git
